perpl.modelling.background_models module¶

background_densities.py

Created on Wed Sep 18 09:55:09 2019

Functions for modelling relative positions among background localisations.

Alistair Curd University of Leeds 16 September 2019

perpl.modelling.background_models.exponential_decay_1d_pair_corr(separation_values, amplitude, scale_param)[source]¶

1D pair-correlation function for localisations where the probability of detection decreases exponentially along the relevant direction, starting from any location (the location parameter of the exponential p.d.f. does not affect the pair-correlation function).

(Derived in Alistair’s lab book, 18/09/2019)

Parameters:

  • separation_values (numpy array) – The separations between localisations, measured along one direction, at which the values of the pair-correlation function will be generated.

  • amplitude (float) – Amplitude of the returned function.

  • scale_param (float) – Scale parameter (1 / decay rate) of the exponential detection p.d.f.. Also the decay rate of the returned function.

Returns:

The 1D pair-correlation function, evaluated at separation_values.

Return type:

rpd (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.background_models.internalbg(separation_values, diameter, amp)[source]¶

Background RPD term modeling isotripc localisations across a disk. See pair_correlation_disk().

Parameters:

  • separation_values (numpy array) – Distances at which density values of the background component will be obtained.

  • diameter (float) – Diameter of the disk containing the background.

  • amp (float) – Amplitude of the background components.

Returns:

The relative position density given by the background model at the separation_values between localisations.

Return type:

rpd (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.background_models.pair_correlation_disk(separation_values, radius)[source]¶

Pair-correlation function for points with uniform density within a disk.

See journal and lab book.

Parameters:

  • separation_values (float) – Separations between two points with the disk.

  • radius (float) – Radius of the disk.

Returns:

Relative position distribution, evaluated at the separation_values between points on the disk. Amplitude is scaled by 10e-7. Provides values for separation_values upto the diameter of the disk.

Return type:

rpd (float)

perpl.modelling.background_models.zero_to_constant_gradient(separation_values, gradient, crossover_distance, variation_amplitude)[source]¶

Function which will tend to zero for low separation values and to a constant gradient at high separation values, relative to a crossover distance.

This can be used as an approximate differentiable background function when modelling XY-separations between Nup107 localisations, where we expect few localisations within the ring structures.

(See notes in Alistair’s lab book 19 Sep 2019.)

Parameters:

  • separation_values (numpy array) – The separations between localisations at which the values of the pair-correlation function will be generated. In the case of the nuclear pore data, for instance, these are distances measured across the XY plane.

  • gradient (float) – The asymptotic gradient for separation_values >> crossover_distance.

  • crossover_distance (float) –

    Characteristic distance for the function.

    If separation_value << crossover_distance,

    result –> 0;

    If separation_value >> crossover_distance,

    result –> separation_value * gradient

  • variation_amplitude (float) – Determines the size of the variation as the function leaves the asymptotes.

Returns:

The values of the background function, evaluated at separation_values.

Return type:

rpd (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis module¶

centriole_analysis.py

Created on Tue Sep 25 12:00:00 2019

Functions for analysing segmented top-view centriolar protein localisations.

Alistair Curd University of Leeds 16 September 2019

— Copyright 2019 Peckham Lab

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.centriole_model_xy_distances_9fold_variable_vertices(separation_values, diameter, vertssd, vertamp1, vertamp2, vertamp3, vertamp4, replocssd, replocsamp, substructsd, substructamp)[source]¶

Parametric model for XY distances between localisations of a centriolar protein.

Parameters:

  • separation_values (numpy array) – Distances at which density values of the model will be obtained.

  • diameter (float) – Diameter of the circle containing the vertices of the polygon.

  • vertssd (float) – Broadening of the peaks located at distances between the vertices.

  • vertamp1 (float) – Amplitudes of the contributions of the different inter-vertex distances.

  • vertamp2 (float) – Amplitudes of the contributions of the different inter-vertex distances.

  • vertamp3 (float) – Amplitudes of the contributions of the different inter-vertex distances.

  • vertamp4 (float) – Amplitudes of the contributions of the different inter-vertex distances.

  • replocssd (float) – Spread representing localisation precision for repeated localisations of the same fluorescent molecule.

  • replocsamp (float) – Amplitude of the contribution of repeated localisations of the same fluorescent molecule.

  • substructsd (float) – Spread of a contribution resulting from unresolvable substructure, or mislocalisations resulting from a combination of simultaneous nearby emitters.

  • substructamp (float) – Amplitude of the contribution of unresolvable substructure, or mislocalisations resulting from a combination of simultaneous nearby emitters.

Returns:

The relative position density given by the model at distances r.

Return type:

rpd (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.centriole_model_xy_distances_9fold_variable_vertices_internal_bg(separation_values, diameter, vertssd, vertamp1, vertamp2, vertamp3, vertamp4, replocssd, replocsamp, substructsd, substructamp, bg_dia, bg_amp)[source]¶

Parametric model for XY distances between localisations of a centriolar protein. Background is modelled as resulting from a disk with isotropic localisations (this provides a reasonable fit to the distance histograms for the less-ordered centriole images).

Parameters:

  • separation_values (numpy array) – Distances at which density values of the model will be obtained.

  • diameter (float) – Diameter of the circle containing the vertices of the polygon.

  • vertssd (float) – Broadening of the peaks located at distances between the vertices.

  • vertamp1 (float) – Amplitudes of the contributions of the different inter-vertex distances.

  • vertamp2 (float) – Amplitudes of the contributions of the different inter-vertex distances.

  • vertamp3 (float) – Amplitudes of the contributions of the different inter-vertex distances.

  • vertamp4 (float) – Amplitudes of the contributions of the different inter-vertex distances.

  • replocssd (float) – Spread representing localisation precision for repeated localisations of the same fluorescent molecule.

  • replocsamp (float) – Amplitude of the contribution of repeated localisations of the same fluorescent molecule.

  • substructsd (float) – Spread of a contribution resulting from unresolvable substructure, or mislocalisations resulting from a combination of simultaneous nearby emitters.

  • substructamp (float) – Amplitude of the contribution of unresolvable substructure, or mislocalisations resulting from a combination of simultaneous nearby emitters.

  • bg_dia (float) – Diameter of the disk containing the modelled background localisations.

  • bg_amp (float) – Amplitude of the background component.

Returns:

The relative position density given by the model at distances r.

Return type:

rpd (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.centriole_model_xy_distances_9fold_variable_vertices_internal_bg_vectorargs(input_vector)[source]¶

Function to calculate the values given by centriole_model_xy_distances_9fold_variable_vertices, but using a vector input for the parameters, so that the numdifftools package can be used to calculate partial derivatives for correct error propagation in the model.

Parameters:

input_vector (list or numpy array) –

A concatenation of:

1. A distance at which density values of the model will be obtained (numpy array)

2. The parameters used by centriole_model_xy_distances_9fold_variable_vertices

Returns:

The relative position density given by the model at the input distances (called separation_values_1d).

Return type:

rpd (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.centriole_model_xy_distances_9fold_variable_vertices_vectorargs(input_vector)[source]¶

A concatenation of:

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.get_input_data(infile='S:/Peckham/Bioimaging2/Alistair/Centriole-EPFL/forAlistair_310718/Cep152_A647_Top.mat')[source]¶

Import and extract a list of dSTORM data on centrioles from Christian Sieben’s MATLAB file.

Parameters:

infile (string) – The path to the data to be extracted.

Returns:

A list of arrays of dSTORM localisations, one element per centriole. For each centriole, columns [0] and [1] of the array are (x, y) for each localisation; column [3] is estimated localisation precision in nm.

Return type:

simul (list of numpy arrays)

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.get_xy_distances(localisations_per_centriole, loc_precision_filter=10.0, filter_distance=1000.0)[source]¶

Get the XY between localisations in each centriole, filtered by localisation precision.

Parameters:

  • centriole_localisations (list of numpy arrays) – A list of arrays of dSTORM localisations, one element per centriole. For each centriole, columns [0] and [1] of the array are (x, y) for each localisation; column [3] is estimated localisation precision in nm.

  • loc_precision_filter (float) – Upper limit on estimated localisation precision. Localisations with an estimate above this value will not be included.

  • filter_distance (float) – Required by relative_positions. Set to 1000 by default to comfortably include all distances in each centriole.

Returns:

List containing the XY-distances found within each centriole, one centriole per list item.

Return type:

distances_xy_per_centriole (list of numpy arrays)

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.main()[source]¶

Do stuff.

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.make_distance_histogram(distance_values, max_distance, normalise=True)[source]¶

Calculate distance histogram bin values, in bins of 1 nm, upto a maximum distance. Bin values will be normalised so that their mean is 1.

Parameters:

  • distance_values (numpy array) – Distances between localisations in a centriole

  • max_distance (float) – Upper limit on distnaces included in the histogram.

  • normalise (bool) – Decide whether to normalise the histograms so that the mean bin value is 1 (good for scipy’s curve_fit on individual centriole data).

Returns:

Distance histogram bin values, normalised so that the mean is 1. bin_edges (numpy array):

Distance histogram bin edge locations.

Return type:

hist (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.make_distance_histograms_per_centriole(distances_per_centriole, max_distance, normalise=True)[source]¶

Make a distance histogram for each centriole.

Parameters:

  • per_centriole (distances) – List containing the XY-distances found within each centriole, one centriole per list item.

  • max_distance (float) – Upper limit on distaces included in the histograms.

  • normalise (bool) – Decide whether to normalise the histograms so that the mean bin value is 1 (good for scipy’s curve_fit on individual centriole data).

Returns:

A list of distance histogram bin values; each row contains the distance histogram for one centriole.

Return type:

dist_hist_list (2D numpy array)

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.make_fit_results_table_variable_vertices_model_9fold_no_bg(distance_histograms_list, model_with_info)[source]¶

Make tables of fitted parameter estimates and uncertainties, and their ratios.

Parameters:

  • distance_histograms_list (list of numpy arrays (e.g. 2D numpy array)) – List with each element being the distance histogram for one centriole image. We assume the distance histograms to have the same length, and the bin centres to be at distances of (integer + 0.5) nm

  • model_with_info (ModelWithFitSettings object) – The model to be fitted, with initial parameter guesses and bounds on allowable parameter values.

Returns:

Dataframe containing the index and fitted parameter

estimates for each distance histogram in distance_histograms_list.

error_on_params_df (pandas dataframe):

Dataframe containing the index and errors on the fitted parameters for each distance histogram in distance_histograms_list.

ratios (pandas dataframe):

Dataframe containing the index and error/estimate ratios for each parameter for each distance histogram in distance_histograms_list.

Return type:

estimated_params_df (pandas dataframe)

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.plot_95_ci(axes, x_values, model, params_optimised, params_covar, vector_input_model)[source]¶

Plot 95% confidence interval for a fitted model.

Parameters:

  • axes – matplotlib Axes on which to plot the CI.

  • x_values (numpy array) – x-values at which to calculate and plot the CI.

  • model (function name) – The parametric model optimised to fit experimental data.

  • params_optimised (numpy array) – The optimised parameters for the fitted model.

  • params_covar (numpy array) – The covariance matrix for the fitted parameters.

  • vector_input_model (function name) – The version of the parametric model with input required to be a vector of the parameter values, for differentiation and error propagation with numdifftools.

Returns:

Standard deviation of the model estimate at each x_value.

Return type:

stdev (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.plot_95_ci_internal_bg(axes, x_values, model, params_optimised, params_covar, bg_dia, vector_input_model_below_bg_dia, vector_input_model_above_bg_dia)[source]¶

Plot 95% confidence interval for a fitted model with internal background. This requires splitting into below and above the diameter of the background disk

Parameters:

  • axes – matplotlib Axes on which to plot the CI.

  • x_values (numpy array) – x-values at which to calculate and plot the CI.

  • model (function name) – The parametric model optimised to fit experimental data.

  • params_optimised (numpy array) – The optimised parameters for the fitted model.

  • params_covar (numpy array) – The covariance matrix for the fitted parameters.

  • bg_dia (float) – The diameter of the background disk of localisations.

  • vector_input_model_below_bg_dia (function name) – The version of the parametric model for separations less than the diameter of the background disk, with input required to be a vector of the parameter values, for differentiation and error propagation with numdifftools.

  • vector_input_model_above_bg_dia (function name) – The version of the parametric model for separations greater than the diameter of the background disk, with input required to be a vector of the parameter values, for differentiation and error propagation with numdifftools.

Returns:

Standard deviation of the model estimate at each x_value.

Return type:

stdev (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.reconstruct_centrioles(centriole_localisation_data, index=None, plot=True, binsize_nm=5.0, smoothing_nm=5.0, color='inferno')[source]¶

Produces centriole reconstructions from localisation data and plots if desired.

Parameters:

  • centriole_localisation_data (list of numpy arrays) – A list of arrays of dSTORM localisations, one element per centriole. For each centriole, columns [0] and [1] of the array are (x, y) for each localisation.

  • index (list) – If desired, the inidices of selected centrioles in the list. If not specified, a reconstruction is produced for all centrioles.

  • plot (Boolean) – Choose whether plots will be produced of each centriole.

  • binsize_nm (float) – The pixel size in the reconstructions, in nm.

  • smoothing_nm (float) – The kernal for Gaussian smoothing of the histogram, in nm.

Returns:

Indices of the chosen centrioles for reconstruction. list_of_reconstructions (list of 2D numpy arrays):

Reconstructions of the centrioles, one centriole per list element.

Return type:

indices (list of integers)

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.select_centrioles_by_error_ratio_threshold_on_peaks(ratios_df, ratio_threshold=0.1, n_peaks_required_below_threshold=2)[source]¶

Choose centrioles based on the number of peaks corresponding to inter-vertex distances) in the fitted model that have error/estimate ratio below a threshold.

Parameters:

  • ratios_df (pandas dataframe) – Dataframe containing the index and error/estimate ratios for each parameter for at least one distance histogram.

  • ratio_threshold (float) – Ratio of error/estimate for peak amplitudes, above which centrioles will be excluded from the selection.

  • n_peaks_required_below_threshold (int) – The number of peaks required to be below the error/estimate threshold, for the distance histogram to be selected.

Returns:

List of indices for centrioles with the required error/estimate ratios for the peak amplitudes corresponding to inter-vertex distances.

Return type:

selected_centriole_numbers (list of integers)

perpl.modelling.centriole_analysis.sum_distance_histograms(distance_histogram_list, normalise=True)[source]¶

Add together distance histograms from a list, to aggregate results over multiple centrioles.

  • normalise (bool) – Decide whether to normalise the histograms so that the mean bin value is 1 (good for scipy’s curve_fit on individual centriole data).

Sum of the distance histograms.

result (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.dna_paint_data_fitting module¶

dna_paint_data_fitting.py

Library of functions for fitting model relative position distributions (RPDs) to relative positions obtained from localisations appearing to be arranged on a relatively simple geometric pattern, i.e. polyhedra.

perpl.modelling.dna_paint_data_fitting.plot_distance_hist_and_fit(distances, fitlength, params_optimised, params_covar, model_with_info, plot_95ci=False, color='xkcd:red')[source]¶
perpl.modelling.dna_paint_data_fitting.plot_model_components_tri_prism(fitlength, side_length, locamp, locprec, structamp, spread, substructamp, substructspread, gridspace, gridamp, gridspread, bgslope)[source]¶

fitlength: distance upto to which the model fit was performed side_length: side length of the triangular prism (all sides equal) locamp: Amplitude of sinlge molecule localisation precision component locprec: Average single molecule localisation precision structamp: Amplitude of components reflecting the structural features

of the complex.

spread: Spread owing to unresolvable complexity or inhomogeneity between

complexes.

substructamp: Amplitude of component reflecting unresolvable substructure

at one vertex.

substructspread: Spread in localisations at one vertex, as a result of

unresolvable substructure there.

gridspace: The spacing of a square grid the complexes are found on. gridamp: Amplitude of components reflecting the nieghbouring complexes at

nearby grid points.

gridspread: Spread owing to different orientation at different grid points. bgslope: Approximate background to 2D (relatively flat); this is the

linear slope.

Returns:

Relative position density as a function of separation between localisations.

initial_params (list):

Starting guesses for the parameter values by scipy.optimize.curve_fit

lower_bounds (list), upper_bounds (list):

The bounds on allowable parameter values as scipy.optimize.curve_fit runs.

Return type:

A ModelWithFitSettings object containing

perpl.modelling.dna_paint_data_fitting.set_up_tri_prism_on_grid_1_length_3disobg_substruct_with_fit_info()[source]¶

Set up the RPD model with fitting settings, for a rotationally symmetric model with spread due to repeated localisations and spread to unresolvable substructure. The fitting settings are to pass to scipy’s curve_fit, and the vector-input version of the model is for differentiation and error propagation with numdifftools.

class perpl.modelling.modelling_general.ModelWithFitSettings(model_rpd, initial_params=None, param_bounds=None, vector_input_model=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Class containing a model relative position distribution (model_rpd) that will be fitted, together with other input required by scipy.optimize.curve_fit.

model_rpd(function)¶

The parameterised model rpd that can be fitted.

initial_params(array_like)¶

Initial guesses for the model parameters to pass to scipy.optimize.curve_fit as p0. If p0 is passed as None, then the initial values used by scipy.optimize.curve_fit will all be 1.

param_bounds(2-tuple of array_like)¶

Lower and upper bounds on parameters to pass to scipy.optimize.curve_fit as bounds. …curve_fit defaults to no bounds if not present. Each element of the tuple must be either an array with the length equal to the number of parameters, or a scalar (in which case the bound is taken to be the same for all parameters.) Use np.inf with an appropriate sign to disable bounds on all or some parameters.

perpl.modelling.modelling_general.correlation_matrix_from_covariance(pcov)[source]¶

Calculate the correlation matrix for parameters from their covariance matrix (pcov).

perpl.modelling.modelling_general.fit_model_to_experiment(expt, model, param_guesses, param_bounds, fitlength=400.0, **kwargs)[source]¶

Use scipy.optimize.curve_fit to do non-linear least-squares fitting of model relative position distribution to an experimental distribution, e.g. histogram or kernel density estimation.

Parameters:

  • expt – Experimental pairwise distance distribution, evaluated at n + 0.5 nm, when n is an integer (histogram bin values).

  • model – Parametric model distribution.

  • param_guesses – Starting guesses for parameter values in scipy’s curve_fit.

  • param_bounds – Bounds on the allowed parameter values during optimisation in scipy’s curve_fit.

  • fitlength – Maximum distance included in the fit.

Returns:

Optimised parameters. params_covar:

Covariance matrix between parameters.

params_1sd_error:

Error (1 SD) on parameters.

Return type:

params_optimised

perpl.modelling.modelling_general.gauss1d(x_values, xmean, sigma)[source]¶

Apparent density of separations(z) for two repeatedly localised fluorophores with true separation rmean, when zmean >> sigma. Sigma = sum in quadrature of sigma for each fluorophore.

perpl.modelling.modelling_general.generate_polygon_points(n, d)[source]¶

Generate the coordinates of points on an polygon.

Parameters:

  • n – Number of vertices.

  • d – Diameter of circle on which the vertices are found.

Returns:

Numpy [x, y] coordinates of vertices. One [x, y] row

per vertex.

Return type:

v

perpl.modelling.modelling_general.kde_1nm(distances, locprec, fitlength)[source]¶

Evaluate KDE of distances between localisations at steps of 1 nm, starting at 0.5 nm. Use localisation precision * np.sqrt(2) as the Gaussian kernel.

Parameters:

  • distances (numpy-like array) –

    Distances between localisations (e.g. axial separation

    in the Z-disk).

  • locprec (float) – Average localisation precision of the localisations involved.

  • fitlength (float) – The distance upto which the KDE will be evaluated.

Returns:

The distances at which the KDE was evaluated. kde (numpy array):

The KDE of the distance distribution, evaluated at x.

Return type:

x (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.modelling_general.linear_fit(x_values, slope, offset)[source]¶

Generate (return) y values for a linear function at given values of x, slope and offset.

perpl.modelling.modelling_general.make_x_histogram_nm(dists, fitlength=400.0, axes=None)[source]¶

Generate a histogram of distances in one direction (e.g. X) between localisations, with 1-nm bins. Bin values averaged so that the mean = 1 (this helps with using scipy.optimise.curve_fit).

Parameters:

  • dists – numpy array of distances between localisations (1D).

  • fitlength – Maximum distance included in the histogram.

Returns:

Histogram bin values with mean = 1. fitlength: Maximum distance included in the histogram.

xyhist

perpl.modelling.modelling_general.pair_corr_2d_standardised(r, rmean, sigma)[source]¶

The main bulding block of the 2D model. Although it does not model the background. Apparent density of separations(r) for two repeatedly localised fluorophores in 2D with true separation rmean, standardised by dividing the separations. sigma = sum in quadrature of sigma for each fluorophore, so sigma ** 2 = 2 * loc.prec ** 2. for repeated locs of the same molecule. From Churchman, Biophys J 90, 668-671 (2006). Need Bessel function, imported as i0(x)

Parameters:

  • r – Numpy array of distances at which you want to evaluate a correlation function.

  • rmean – Single float value that is the mean distance between the 2 Gaussian densities.

  • function. (sigma is the spread of the Gaussian)

Returns:

Numpy array of the probability density of the correclation function

at the values of r.

Return type:

p

perpl.modelling.modelling_general.pairwise_correlation_1d(z, zmean, sigma)[source]¶

Apparent density of separations(z) for two repeatedly localised fluorophores with true separation rmean. Sigma = sum in quadrature of sigma for each fluorophore, so sigma ** 2 = 2 * loc.prec ** 2. for repeated locs of the same molecule. From Churchman, Biophys J 90, 668-671 (2006). Need Bessel function, imported as j0(x)

perpl.modelling.modelling_general.pairwise_correlation_2d(r, rmean, sigma)[source]¶

The main bulding block of the 2D model. Although it does not model the background. Apparent density of separations(r) for two repeatedly localised fluorophores in 2D with true separation rmean. sigma = sum in quadrature of sigma for each fluorophore, so sigma ** 2 = 2 * loc.prec ** 2. for repeated locs of the same molecule. From Churchman, Biophys J 90, 668-671 (2006). Need Bessel function, imported as i0(x)

Parameters:

  • r – Numpy array of distances at which you want to evaluate a correlation function.

  • rmean – Single float value that is the mean distance between the 2 Gaussian densities.

  • function. (sigma is the spread of the Gaussian)

Returns:

Numpy array of the probability density of the correclation function

at the values of r.

Return type:

p

From Churchman, Biophys J 90, 668-671 (2006). Need Bessel function, imported as i0(x) :param r: :param r_mean: :param sigma:

perpl.modelling.modelling_general.rotate_3d_vectors(vectors, axis, angle)[source]¶

Rotate 3D vectors (or coordinates) by an angle about an axis. Normalise the axis vector so that it does not need to be already normalised when passed to this function.

Parameters:

  • vectors (numpy array, shape (n, 3), where columns are XYZ) – 3D vectors to be rotated.

  • axis (numpy array, shape (3,)) – Vector with direction of the rotation axis.

  • angle (float) – Angle of rotation about the axis (degrees).

Returns:

rotated_vectors – Input vectors rotated according to the input parameters.

Return type:

numpy array, shape (n, 3)

perpl.modelling.modelling_general.stdev_of_model(x_values, params_optimised, params_covar, vector_input_model)[source]¶

Use automatic differentiation to acquire derivatives, and multiply with covariance matrix to acquire variance, then sd of a model relative position distribution. When numdifftools.Gradient runs, output to screen from the function it is differentiating is suppressed.

Parameters:

  • x_values (numpy array) – Distances at which the model is evaluated.

  • params_optimised (numpy array) – The optimised parameter values of the model, following a fit to experimental data.

  • params_covar (numpy array) – The covariance matrix for the parameters that have been optimised.

  • vector_input_model (function) – The name of a function that will be passed to numdifftools.Gradient. This function must have one arguments, which is a vector. The first element of the vector is also the vector of x_values.

Returns:

Numpy array of 1 standard deviation of uncertaintly on the model evaluated at each x_value.

Return type:

stdev (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.polyhedramodelling module¶

polyhedramodelling.py

Library of non-statistical functions needed to create the polyhedral models.

Created on Thu Jun 20 16:32:11 2019

Alistair Curd University of Leeds 30 July 2018

Software Engineering practices applied

Joanna Leng (an EPSRC funded Research Software Engineering Fellow (EP/R025819/1) University of Leeds January 2019

— Copyright 2018 Peckham Lab

perpl.modelling.polyhedramodelling.cube_on_grid_2disobg_substructure_rpd(r, a, locamp, locprec, structamp, spread, substructamp, substructspread, gridspace, gridamp, gridspread, bgslope)[source]¶

r are distances over which the model needs to be evaluated, e.g. 0.5, 1.5, 2.5, 3.5, … nm a, b, c: cuboid side lengths locamp: Amplitude of sinlge molecule localisation precision component locprec: Average single molecule localisation precision structamp: Amplitude of components reflecting the structural features

of the complex.

spread: Spread owing to unresolvable complexity or inhomogeneity between

complexes.

substructamp: Amplitude of component reflecting unresolvable substructure

at one vertex.

substructspread: Spread in localisations at one vertex, as a result of

unresolvable substructure there.

gridspace: The spacing of a square grid the complexes are found on. gridamp: Amplitude of components reflecting the nieghbouring complexes at

nearby grid points.

gridspread: Spread owing to different orientation at different grid points. bgslope: Approximate background to 2D (relatively flat); this is the

linear slope.

perpl.modelling.polyhedramodelling.tri_prism_on_grid_1_length_2disobg_substruct_rpd_vectorargs(input_vector)[source]¶

Function to calculate the values given by tri_prism_on_grid_1_length_2disobg_substruct_rpd, but using a vector input for the parameters, so that the numdifftools package can be used to calculate partial derivatives for correct error propagation in the model.

Parameters:

input_vector (list or numpy array) –

A concatenation of:

1. A distance at which density values of the model will be obtained (numpy array)

2. The parameters used by tri_prism_on_grid_2disobg_substructure_rpd.

Returns:

The relative position density given by the model at the input distances (called separation_values_1d).

Return type:

rpd (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.two_layer_fitting module¶

two_layer_fitting.py

Functions for fitting relative positions of localisations to a two layer model.

perpl.modelling.two_layer_fitting.fit_two_layer_model(experimental_data, model=<function two_layer_model_constant_bg>, fitlength=200.0)[source]¶

Use scipy.optimize.curve_fit to do non-linear least-squares fitting of a model two-layer relative position distribution to an experimental distribution, e.g. histogram or kernel density estimation. :param experimental_data: Experimental pairwise distance distribution along one

direction, evaluated at n + 0.5 nm, where n is an integer (histogram bin centres for distance histograms).

Parameters:

  • model – Parametric model distribution. Defaults to two_layer_model().

  • fitlength – Maximum distance included in the fit.

Returns:

Optimised parameters. params_covar:

Covariance matrix between parameters.

params_1sd_err:

Error (1 SD) on parameters.

Return type:

params_optimised

perpl.modelling.two_layer_fitting.get_input(info)[source]¶

Load relative positions.

Returns:

Relative position data (2D or 3D) loaded from .csv file.

perpl.modelling.two_layer_fitting.log_file_header(log_file, info)[source]¶

Writes key info to the top of the log file. We continually write to the log file and the script is executed so we have something if it crashes.

Parameters:

  • log_file (file handler) – Allows you to write to the already open log file.

  • info (dict) – A python dictionary containing a collection of useful parameters such as the filenames and paths.

Returns:

Nothing is returned.

perpl.modelling.two_layer_fitting.main()[source]¶

GET DATA AND RUN ANALYSIS.

perpl.modelling.two_layer_fitting.two_layer_model_constant_bg(distance_values_1d, layer_separation, amplitude_within_layer, amplitude_between_layers, broadening, background_offset)[source]¶

Generate the values of a relative position density (RPD) for a two-layer, 1D distribution. Comprised of two pair-correlation functions for Gaussian distributions (within and between the two layers), plus a constant background density value (assuming isotropic localisations).

Parameters:

  • distance_values_1d (numpy array) – The separations between localisations, measured along one direction, at which the values of the RPD will be generated.

  • layer_separation (float) – The separation between the two layers of the model structure.

  • amplitude_within_layer (float) – The amplitude of the peak of the distribution describing within-layer separations.

  • broadening (float) – Reflects the spread of each layer, assumed to be the same for both.

  • background_offset – Constant background density for an isotropic sample.

perpl.modelling.two_layer_fitting.two_layer_model_exp_decay_bg(distance_values_1d, layer_separation, amplitude_within_layer, amplitude_between_layers, broadening, bg_amplitude, bg_scale_param)[source]¶

Generate the values of a relative position density (RPD) for a two-layer, 1D distribution. Comprised of two pair-correlation functions for Gaussian distributions (within and between the two layers), plus an exponentially decaying background density function (e.g. as arising from localisations in Z in the evanescent field in a TIRF experiment).

Parameters:

  • distance_values_1d (numpy array) – The separations between localisations, measured along one direction, at which the values of the RPD will be generated.

  • layer_separation (float) – The separation between the two layers of the model structure.

  • amplitude_within_layer (float) – The amplitude of the peak of the distribution describing within-layer separations.

  • broadening (float) – Reflects the spread of each layer, assumed to be the same for both.

  • bg_amplitude – Amplitude of the exponentially decaying background density.

  • bg_scale_param – Scale parameter for the exponentially decaying background term.

perpl.modelling.two_layer_fitting.two_layer_model_exp_decay_bg_vectorargs(input_vector)[source]¶

Function to calculate the values given by two_layer_model_exp_decay_bg, but using a vector input for the parameters, so that the numdifftools package can be used to calculate partial derivatives for correct error propagation in the model.

Parameters:

input_vector (list or numpy array) –

A concatenation of:

1. Distances at which density values of the model will be obtained (numpy array)

2. The parameters used by two_layer_model_exp_decay_bg (list or numpy vector).

Returns:

The relative position density given by the model at the input distances (called separation_values_1d).

Return type:

rpd (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.zdisk_modelling.create_default_fitting_params_dicts()[source]¶

Create lists for initial guesses and bounds for parameters during fitting. Sets the defaults for scipy.optimise.curve_fit

Returns:

Dictionary of default lower bound options for parameter values. upper_bound_dict (dict):

Dictionary of default upper bound options for parameter values.

initial_params_dict (dict):

lower_bound_dict (dict)

perpl.modelling.zdisk_modelling.fitmodel_to_hist(x, experimentaldist, model=<function linrepplusreps5fixedpeakratio>, initial_params=None, param_bounds=None)[source]¶

Fit model to distance histogram. Designed to allow user editting of parameter guesses and bounds for models of RPDs for linear repeating models, as in linearrepeatmodels.py.

Parameters:

  • x – Distance values at which the experimental distribution of distances and the model are evaluated.

  • experimentaldist – The values of the experimental distribution of distances. Can be e.g. histogram or KDE.

  • model – The model for the RPD.

  • fitlength – The maximum distance that may be included in the fit.

perpl.modelling.zdisk_modelling.get_transverse_separations(relpos, max_distance=100.0, axial_limit=10.0)[source]¶

Get axial separations between localisations, also within a limited transverse distance of one another.

Parameters:

  • relpos – Relative positions containing .axial and .transverse distance (e.g. pandas dataframe).

  • max_distance – The maximum transverse separation upto which data will be analysed.

  • axial_limit – The maximum distance along the cell-axis between localisations involved.

Returns:

The axial separations as desired, sorted from lowest to highest.

Return type:

sorted_trans_points

perpl.modelling.zdisk_modelling.getaxialseparations_no_smoothing(relpos, max_distance=100.0, transverse_limit=10.0)[source]¶

Get axial separations between localisations, also within a limited transverse distance of one another.

  • relpos – Relative positions containing .axial and .transverse distance (e.g. pandas dataframe).

  • max_distance – The maximum axial separation upto which data will be modelled.

  • transverselimit – The maximum distance across the transverse plane between localisations involved.

The axial separations as desired, sorted from lowest to highest.

sorted_axpoints

Get axial separations between localisations, also within a limited transverse distance of one another.

  • locprec – Average localisation precision of the localisations involved.

axpoints

perpl.modelling.zdisk_modelling.read_relpos_from_pickles(input_files)[source]¶

relpos (numpy-like array)

perpl.modelling.zdisk_modelling.remove_duplicates(sortedrelpos)[source]¶

Slice relative positions so that duplicates are removed. This can be necessary when absolute amplitude of the histograms/density is important.

perpl.modelling.zdisk_modelling.set_up_model_2d_onepeak_plus_replocs_flat_bg_with_fit_settings()[source]¶

Set up the RPD model with fitting settings.

This model has one peak representing a characteristic distance, as well as repeated localisations. Only uniform background level.

The fitting settings are to pass to scipy’s curve_fit, and the vector-input version of the model is for differentiation and error propagation with numdifftools.

Parameters:

None

Returns:

model_rpd (function name):

Relative position density as a function of separation between localisations.

initial_params (list):

Starting guesses for the parameter values by scipy.optimize.curve_fit

lower_bounds (list), upper_bounds (list):

The bounds on allowable parameter values as scipy.optimize.curve_fit runs.

Return type:

A ModelWithFitSettings object containing

perpl.modelling.zdisk_modelling.set_up_model_5_peaks_fixed_ratio_no_replocs_with_fit_settings()[source]¶

Set up the RPD model with fitting settings.

This model has five peaks on a linear repeats, with linear decreasing amplitude, above a linear sloping backgroung, with no component for repeated localisations.

The fitting settings are to pass to scipy’s curve_fit, and the vector-input version of the model is for differentiation and error propagation with numdifftools.

Parameters:

None

perpl.modelling.zdisk_modelling.set_up_model_5_variable_peaks_after_offset_flat_bg_with_fit_settings()[source]¶

Set up the RPD model with fitting settings.

This model has a term for repeated localisations, followed by peaks at offset + n * repeat distance, where is 1-5. With a flat background term.

The fitting settings are to pass to scipy’s curve_fit, and the vector-input version of the model is for differentiation and error propagation with numdifftools.

Parameters:

None

Returns:

model_rpd (function name):

Relative position density as a function of separation between localisations.

perpl.modelling.zdisk_plots module¶

zdisk_plots.py

Functions for plotting figures for manuscript on PERPL technique.

perpl.modelling.zdisk_plots.actn_mEos_x_plot()[source]¶
perpl.modelling.zdisk_plots.lasp_mEos_plot()[source]¶

Fit axial KDE of relative positions of myopalladin:mEos localisations.

Fit axial KDE of relative positions of myopalladin:mEos localisations.

perpl.modelling.zdisk_plots.plot_distance_hist(distances, fitlength, color='gray')[source]¶

Plot histogram of experimental distances, with 1 nm bins.

Parameters:

  • distances (numpy array-like) – Set of distances (nm) to plot.

  • fitlength (float) – The distance upto which the histogram will be calculated.

  • color (string) – Colour for the matplotlib histogram.

Returns:

Histogram bin values. bin_edges (numpy array):

Histogram bin edge positions.

Return type:

hist_values (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.zdisk_plots.plot_distance_hist_and_fit(axpoints, fitlength, params_optimised, params_covar, model_with_info, plot_95ci=False, color='xkcd:red')[source]¶
perpl.modelling.zdisk_plots.plot_distance_kde(distances, locprec, fitlength, color='gray')[source]¶

Plot KDE (using localisation precision) of experimental distances.

Parameters:

  • distances (numpy array-like) – Set of distances (nm) to plot.

  • locprec – Average localisation precision of the localisations involved.

  • fitlength (float) – The distance upto which the KDE will be evaluated.

  • color (string) – Colour for the shaded KDE.

Returns:

Distances at which the kde is evaluated. kde (numpy array):

The density estimated at kde_x_points.

Return type:

kde_x_values (numpy array)

perpl.modelling.zdisk_plots.plot_fitted_model(axpoints, fitlength, params_optimised, params_covar, model_with_info, plot_95ci=False, color='xkcd:red')[source]¶

Plot model fitted to experimental data, with or without confidence intervals.

perpl.modelling.zdisk_plots.plot_model_components_4peaks_fixed_peak_ratio(fitlength, repeat_distance, repeat_broadening, repeat_amplitude, loc_precision, loc_precision_amplitude, bg_slope, bg_offset)[source]¶

Plot the components of this Z-disk model. :param fitlength (integer): Cell-axial distance upto to which the model is plotted. :param repeat_distance (float): Axial repeat distance through the Z-disk. :param repeat_broadening (float): Broadening on the cell-axial repeat term. :param repeat_amplitude (float): Amplitude of the first peak of the 4. Amplitudes decrease

with ratios 4:3:2:1.

Parameters:

  • (float) (bg_offset) – Broadening on the peak representing repeated localisations of the same molecule.

  • (float) – Amplitude of the peak representing repeated localisations of the same molecule.

  • (float) – Slope of the background term (isotropic within the thickness of the Z-disk)

  • (float) – Value of the background term at distance = 0.

perpl.modelling.zdisk_plots.plot_model_components_5peaks_variable(distance_values, repeat_distance, repeat_broadening, peak1_amplitude, peak2_amplitude, peak3_amplitude, peak4_amplitude, peak5_amplitude, bg_slope, bg_offset)[source]¶

Plot the components of this Z-disk model. :param fitlength (integer): Cell-axial distance upto to which the model is plotted. :param repeat_distance (float): Axial repeat distance through the Z-disk. :param repeat_broadening (float): Broadening on the cell-axial repeat term. :param peak1_amplitude (float): Amplitude of the first peak due to the linear repeating pattern

of localisations.

Parameters:

  • (float) (bg_offset) – As peak1_amplitude, but for peaks 2 to 5.

  • (float) – Slope of the background term (isotropic within the thickness of the Z-disk)

  • (float) – Value of the background term at distance = 0.
